column4: i am using fedora 12 right now and want to upgrade to a newer distro - i was wonderin what some of the advantages of ubuntu might be... i'm a web developer so I'm needing some dev tools/services but also want something with a nice gui and application set, etc.

well i code in php, so it would be nice to have some IDE tools.... plus gimp, inkscape, and other graphic stuff.... i dont think it's anything too different - just wondering about comparing fedora to ubuntu in general
there are lots of IDEs in ubuntu
does ubuntu have a comparable package repository compared to fedora? i know some distros like to be stripped down, forcing you to install from source individually
and also multimedia - ie movies, mp3's, etc..
there is a handy pair of packages which will pull in pretty much all you can need:  ubuntu-restricted-extras    and by adding the medibuntu repo: w32codecs
desktop has a desktop, server doesn't and is also optomised for background processes
if you want a mouse based interface to the system, install the desktop
now if i have an AMDx64 chip, should i still get the 32-bit version?

yes, most 64bit CPUs can emulate 32bit, which is why you could run 32bit XP on your 64bit CPU. If you have more than 3Gb RAM you may want to look at 64bit ubuntu. You can se 32bit Ubuntu with PAE kernel and access 64Gb RAM though
if you install vlc and gnome-mplayer it will pull in a tonne of codecs. You can also add the w32codecs package from medibuntu repo to maybe get what you need
how come that's not mentioned in the shortcuts screen?
was just curious how to find out what the shortcuts are.... seems to all be listed under the system settings
hold superL (aka 'windows key') and you'll see them
